Introduction

Esophageal perforation is a rare, life-threatening condition characterized by a full-thickness tear in the esophageal wall, often related to forceful, protracted vomiting (ie, Boerhaave syndrome) or endoscopic injury.  Efflux of esophageal fluid and air into the mediastinum causes severe chest pain, dyspnea, suprasternal crepitus, and a systemic inflammatory response that can quickly progress to septic shock and death.  The diagnosis is confirmed by CT scan or esophagography, which reveals extravasation of contrast from the esophagus.  Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, proton pump inhibitors, and emergency surgical repair.

Pathophysiology



The majority of esophageal perforations are iatrogenic, caused by inadvertent injury during endoscopic procedures.  When spontaneous perforations occur, they are typically related to effort rupture (ie, Boerhaave syndrome), which is characterized by a sudden increase in intraesophageal pressure and a decrease in intrathoracic pressure (eg, forceful retching, straining) that causes a transmural esophageal tear.  Tears occur most often on the left posterolateral wall of the distal esophagus due to intrinsic weakness in this area.  Subsequent leakage of esophageal and gastric contents into the sterile mediastinum can rapidly lead to mediastinitis, septic shock, and death.

Risk factors



  • Esophageal instrumentation:  endoscopy, biopsy
  • Boerhaave syndrome:  rapid increase in intraesophageal pressure
    • Prolonged or severe retching/vomiting:  chronic alcohol use, hyperemesis gravidarum, bulimia nervosa
    • Straining:  weight lifting, stooling, childbirth
  • Esophagitis (eg, caustic, pill, or infectious):  may weaken the esophageal wall, making it more susceptible to rupture
  • Foreign body ingestion/impaction:  can cause direct wall perforation or lead to pressure necrosis
  • Blunt or penetrating trauma to the chest or abdomen

Clinical presentation



Symptoms of acute esophageal perforation include:



  • Severe retrosternal chest, back, or epigastric pain
  • Dyspnea, tachypnea, or respiratory distress (likely due to pleural irritation and free air in the mediastinum)
  • Neck pain, odynophagia, hoarseness, dysphonia (typically observed in proximal esophageal tears)


Characteristic examination findings:



  • Crepitus in the neck or chest:  esophageal air leaking into the mediastinum (ie, pneumomediastinum) causing subcutaneous emphysema
  • Signs of systemic inflammation/sepsis:  fever, tachycardia, hypotension (symptoms may take several hours to develop)
  • Hamman sign:  crunching sound heard in the precordium with each heartbeat
  • Pleural effusion containing gastrointestinal fluids (eg, green with food particles):  esophageal contents moving through the perforation and into the pleural space

Diagnosis



Esophageal perforation should be suspected in any patient with sudden onset of chest, back, or epigastric pain with associated crepitus and a recent history of protracted vomiting or endoscopy.  Diagnosis is confirmed by CT scan or esophagography that shows extravasation of oral contrast from the esophagus.

Differential diagnosis



  • Aortic dissection:  causes rapid onset of severe chest pain that radiates to the back; x-ray of the chest may show a widened mediastinum and unilateral pleural effusion (hemothorax).  However, aortic dissection is often associated with pulse deficits, blood pressure variation between extremities, and a new murmur, not fever or crepitus.
  • Acute myocardial infarction:  associated with severe chest pressure that may radiate to the back or neck with dyspnea, but fever and subcutaneous emphysema would not be expected.
  • Esophageal foreign body:  objects lodged in the esophagus (eg, food bolus, fish bone) can cause chest pain, odynophagia, and dysphagia, but patients can typically report the specific ingestion that incited their symptoms.
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax:  characterized by abrupt onset of chest pain, shortness of breath, subcutaneous emphysema, and air in the pleural space.  Patients are typically tall, thin men or have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.  Systemic illness (eg, fever) is not typical.
  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome:  represents a partial-thickness (mucosal) esophageal tear.  Although it can occur with repeated vomiting, it most commonly presents as hematemesis and would not cause pneumomediastinum on chest imaging (which indicates a full-thickness perforation).

Laboratory evaluation



Laboratory values are often nonspecific but may support the diagnosis and assess severity of illness.



  • Complete blood count (CBC):  Leukocytosis suggests systemic inflammation or infection.
  • Complete metabolic panel:  Acid-base abnormalities and renal/liver dysfunction may occur with septic shock.
  • Blood culture and sensitivity:  There is a high incidence of sepsis after esophageal perforation.
  • Pleural fluid analysis:  Pleural fluid with an esophageal origin will have a low pH, high amylase (leaked saliva), and green color with food particles (gastrointestinal contents).

Imaging



The initial evaluation of esophageal perforation often includes an x-ray of the chest, which may reveal a widened mediastinum, pneumomediastinum or pneumothorax (due to leaked air), or pleural effusion (due to leaked fluid).  However, these findings are not sensitive or specific for esophageal perforation, and advanced imaging is needed to confirm the diagnosis.



The diagnosis is confirmed by visualizing oral contrast extravasation from the esophagus into surrounding tissues.  Two reliable modalities for this evaluation are:



  • Esophagography (
    image 1
    ):  Fluoroscopic x-ray captures images of the esophagus as contrast is swallowed.
  • CT scan of chest and abdomen with oral contrast (
    image 2
    ):  This can also evaluate for associated complications such as mediastinitis or abscess.

Management



Rapid diagnosis and treatment are essential because delays in care greatly increase mortality.  Patients are typically admitted to receive intensive care and treated as follows:



  • Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics:  to cover both aerobic and anaerobic organisms
  • Intravenous proton pump inhibitors:  to reduce gastric acid and limit caustic fluid leakage
  • Discontinuation of all enteral intake
  • Emergent surgical consultation for operative management including primary repair of esophageal perforation, drainage of mediastinal or pleural fluid collections (if present), and debridement of any necrotic tissue

Complications



The most significant complication of esophageal perforation is mediastinitis.



  • Mediastinitis:  a serious condition characterized by inflammation and infection of the mediastinum, the area in the middle of the chest that contains the heart, trachea, great vessels, and other vital structures.  Infection can spread quickly within this space and into the systemic circulation (eg, sepsis) rapidly leading to septic shock and death.


Additional complications include:



  • Pleural effusion/empyema:  Leakage of esophageal and gastric contents into the chest cavity can cause the accumulation of fluid (pleural effusion) or pus (empyema) in the pleural cavity.  This can cause dyspnea and respiratory distress.
  • Abscess formation:  Pockets of pus may form within the chest cavity, leading to the formation of abscesses.
  • Fistula formation:  Significant localized inflammation resulting from an esophageal perforation can cause an abnormal connection (fistula) between the esophagus and adjacent structures such as the trachea or bronchi.  This increases the risk of aspiration/infection and respiratory failure.
  • Hemorrhage:  Severe bleeding may occur, especially if blood vessels are damaged during the esophageal tear or if nearby blood vessels undergo erosion.

Prognosis



Mortality rates from esophageal perforation are high.  Delays in diagnosis and treatment permit ongoing contamination of the typically sterile mediastinum, leading to sepsis, shock, and death.  Esophageal perforations are not common and they present similarly to several other clinical conditions, so a high index of suspicion is required to avoid missing the diagnosis.  Early recognition and timely management are essential for optimizing outcomes and reducing mortality.
